title: Statue Of Liberty National Monument: Museum Collection
body: Museum Collection        The park's museum collection represents both the cultural and natural resources of Liberty and Ellis Islands. All the items in the museum collection are documented in the computerized database of the National Park Service, Department of the Interior Collection Management System (ICMS). The guidelines that are used to determine the decision to accept an item to the museum collection are outlined in the park's Scope of Collections Statement and generally follow the categories below: Archeology: the Native American and historic use of Liberty and Ellis Islands Early European use of Liberty and Ellis Islands, including the construction of Fort Wood and Fort Gibson as part of the military defense system of New York       History of the Statue of Liberty, its construction, architecture and restoration The Statue of Liberty's image in popular culture The Statue of Liberty as a symbol      The history and use of Ellis Island as an immigration station and hospital from 1892 to 1954 Ellis Island's use by other government agencies and the military From Immigration Station to Museum      Natural Resources Collection Research and Donations
